abstract.p: A grant of a mortmain license to the mayor, burgesses and commonality of Bristol so that they can acquire the lands of the house or hospital of St. Bartholomew in Bristol, Gloucestershire and elsewhere in England.

The grant is enrolled on the Patent Roll for 23 Henry VIII (22 April 1531 - 21 April 1532) (TNA, C 66/659, m. 36), which is calendared in Letters and Papers, Foreign and Domestic, Henry VIII, V, 909 (20).

Per breve de priuato sigillo et de data predicta auctoritate parliamenti

Henry the Eighth, by the Grace of God, King of England and France Defender of the Faith and Lord of Ireland. To all to whom these present letters shall come, greetings. Know that we considering the good purpose of our beloved Thomas West, knight, Lord La Warr, George Croft our chaplain, Robert Thorne, Nicholas Thorne of our town of Bristol and John Godryche, clerk, executor of the will of Robert Thorne, deceased, in the foundation, continuation and support of a certain grammar school in the said town of Bristol or in the suburbs of the same town for children in the same school to be instructed in good manners and learning for the better maintenance of one master and one usher or two ushers of the same and other things necessary which are to be made in the same place, of our special grace and from certain knowledge and by our mere motion we have granted and given license and by these presents we grant and give license for us and our heirs in so far as we are able to the mayor, burgesses and commonality of the said town of Bristol and their successors that themselves and their successors be able to acquire and receive the house or hospital of Saint Bartholomew in our said town of Bristol, and the demense lands, manors, messuages, lands, tenements, gardens, orchards, meadows, grazing, pastures, rents, reversions, services with all their rights, profits and advantages which are now or any time past have been accepted or considered or parcel of the same hospital or which the said George Croft master of the said hospital had held or was enjoying in right of the same hospital in the said town of Bristol and in the parish of Clyfton, Stapulton, Sodbury and Wyckwarr in our county of Gloucestershire or elsewhere in the county of the said town of Bristol of Gloucestershire or elsewhere within this our kingdom of England to the yearly value of forty pounds over and above all burdens and deductions both of the said Thomas West knight lord La Warr true patron and founder of the said hospital and of the said George Crofte master and custodian of the said house or hospital and of the brothers and sisters of the same house or hospital or of any of them or of whichever other persons or person having or claiming to have or anytime hereafter should happen to have some right, title, enjoyed possession or interest of and in the premisses or any parcel thereof if is held of us in chief or of other persons or person directly or indirectly; which is to be held to themselves and their successora in perpetuity. And the same person or same persons themselves are able and can give, grant, bequeth or assign the said house or hospital, demense lands, manors, lands, tenements and other premisses with their appurtenances to the mayor, burgesses and commonality of the said town and their aforesaid successors to the said yearly value in the said form. Similarly we have given and granted and we give and grant special licence by these presents without hinderance, claim or injury of our heirs or of our successors, justices, escheaters, sheriffs, bailiffs or other our ministers whatsoever. Moreover we wish and grant by these presents to the same mayor and burgesses and commonality of the said town of Bristol and their successors that themselves and their successors may have and possess or they can have or possess both our present letters patent and all and every kind of writ and royal letters of execution and confirmation which is to be made and done from time to time. Without any fine or fee thenceforth by whatever means which is to be taxed, imposed, made, paid or taken in the Chancery of us, of our heirs and successors, or in the Hanaper of the same our Chancery or elsewhere. And that the Keeper or Clerk of the aforesaid Hanaper or his deputy in the same place for the time being shall be quit thereof and shall be exonerated forever in their account which is to be returned to the Exchequer of us and our heirs; the statute of not putting lands and tenements in mortmain or any other statutes, acts, ordinances, restrictions or instructions made, proclaimed or ordained or which is to be made or ordained to the contrary or any other cause, thing or matter whatsoever not withstanding. And without prosecuting or causing to be made any writ or writs of ad quod dampnum `to what damage' of us, of our heirs and successors, for the premisses or any premisses. Or although in our present letters patents express mention is not made of the certainty of the premisses or of any other gifts of concessions formerly made by us or any of our progenitors to the aforesaid mayor, burgesses and commonality of the said town of Bristol and their successor before made not withstanding. In witness of which thing we suffer these letters to be made patent. Witnessed by myself at Chelsea the seventeenth day of March the twenty third year of our reign. Popeley. By the writ of the privy seal and of the date aforesaid. By authority of Parliament.
